title: Kubernetes 1.35: 10 new Alpha features
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-11-26, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fplatformengineering.org%2Fblog%2Fkubernetes-1-35-10-new-alpha-features%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019ac00f64b3-f4e69e43-6f62-4634-8239-0c4a49a3d889-000000/FuzM53u1a13EovV6Rp-6ux2GdnLxXL2tC1_BbQH5EGw=433
summary: Kubernetes 1.35: 10 new Alpha features (6 minute read) Kubernetes 1.35 introduces 10 new alpha features, including Dynamic Resource Allocation improvements for binding conditions and partitionable devices, that aim to better orchestrate AI-native workloads. Other highlights include a Mixed Version Proxy to address version skew during upgrades, CSI driver options to receive generated service account tokens in secrets, and a framework for nodes to declare available Kubernetes features.

title: Why I love Linux
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-11-26, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fit-notes.dragas.net%2F2025%2F11%2F24%2Fwhy-i-still-love-linux%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019ac00f64b3-f4e69e43-6f62-4634-8239-0c4a49a3d889-000000/YLsxaRHoJHBPG451KIahl__dLnIjsKQGBsXO0IJBa_U=433
summary: Why I (still) love Linux (12 minute read) Linux provides unmatched freedom, accessibility, and longevity, even as many modern distributions drift from classic Unix principles and introduce instability in the name of progress. Despite frustrations like systemd's scope creep and corporate influence on development direction, Linux remains deeply valuable thanks to its hardware support, minimalistic distributions, and the decades of learning, growth, and reliability it has enabled.

title: Demystifying Determinism in Durable Execution
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-11-26, Reading time: 8 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fjack-vanlightly.com%2Fblog%2F2025%2F11%2F24%2Fdemystifying-determinism-in-durable-execution%3Futm_source=tldrdevops/1/0100019ac00f64b3-f4e69e43-6f62-4634-8239-0c4a49a3d889-000000/PViu4ElXO5I1pmXoY_zlq7EGKYZRRgLJbbxF8jyZxuE=433
summary: Demystifying Determinism in Durable Execution (8 minute read) Durable execution frameworks recover by re-running a function from the top and reusing previously recorded side-effect results, which means the control flow must be fully deterministic so that every retry makes the same decisions and passes the same arguments. Side effects themselves can be non-deterministic, but they must be idempotent or duplication-tolerant because they may be re-invoked if their results weren't durably recorded.

title: On Idempotency Keys
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-11-27, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.morling.dev%2Fblog%2Fon-idempotency-keys%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019ac4ff60d7-67d69cc4-79a4-4e4c-a56b-3e65a7b7a27f-000000/knmeT4jSQ_YXhFgIi9kIRvA-mE9ID7C1cJc62rjYGW4=433
summary: On Idempotency Keys (7 minute read) Idempotency keys enable exact-once processing in distributed systems by letting consumers detect and skip duplicate messages from at-least-once deliveries, using atomic persistence to make retries safe. Common approaches include random or time-based UUIDs for simplicity, monotonic sequences or database WAL positions (via CDC) for storage efficiency and natural ordering. The best choice depends on scale, concurrency needs, and operational complexity.

comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2025-11-27, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Faiven.io%2Fblog%2Fbuilding-agentic-rag-with-postgresql-and-n8n%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019ac4ff60d7-67d69cc4-79a4-4e4c-a56b-3e65a7b7a27f-000000/jRtvcmxq1qeWWQDlOGr-VTrs5PqHi58OOg0XTkRP7ew=433

summary: A Cell So Minimal That It Challenges Definitions of Life (15 minute read) Scientists have discovered a single-celled organism with a fantastically small genome. The cell is so stripped of essential functions that it challenges biologists' definitions of life. Its lost genes include those central to cell metabolism - the cell can neither process nutrients nor grow its own. The cell appears to be a parasite entirely dependent on a host or cellular community.
